componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks for the question. Vis-à-vis a more aggressive introduction of new experiences, it's already starting. It'll certainly continue this quarter even through the holiday. If you think about it, the least disruptive is exogenous through search chan
componenttext: Yes. Thanks for the question. Vis-à-vis a more aggressive introduction of new experiences, it's already starting. It'll certainly continue this quarter even through the holiday. If you think about it, the least disruptive is exogenous through search channels, then category and browse pages, which we're sort of introducing right now and you'll see us drive a number of holiday campaigns directly to those experiences for the first time. And then the final one, which is the biggest channel but the one that we have to be the most careful about is the organic search channel. So we're not going to do that through this holiday. We will do more category in landing pages. We'll do more holiday campaigns to take you to those experiences, but we're not going to mess around with our core search funnel as we get ready for holiday. You can expect us to start to do that next year. On social, Colin, we are very aggressive about that. And by the way, top of the funnel, when we talk about brand marketing, I think it sometimes gets conflated with TV. TV is not the largest part of it. It's brand across all channels, including social. So this quarter, we added an 18th social channel. We're working aggressively with multiple social channels, including what I mentioned in my remarks, launching a bot on Facebook Messenger, but we're advertising. And you'll see eBay brand messages in addition to bottom-of-the-funnel call-to-action messages increasingly across major social and messaging platforms.

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Douglas Anmuth from JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Douglas Anmuth from JPMorgan.

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 I wanted to ask. First, Scott, just on the 4Q outlook. Can you just talk about the revenue guide, the FX-neutral 4% to 6% and just some of the drivers there in terms of that being down from the 8% in 3Q? Obviously, a tougher comp on StubHub but j
componenttext: I have 2 I wanted to ask. First, Scott, just on the 4Q outlook. Can you just talk about the revenue guide, the FX-neutral 4% to 6% and just some of the drivers there in terms of that being down from the 8% in 3Q? Obviously, a tougher comp on StubHub but just hoping you can expand there. And then second, I think last quarter, you talked about having a 10% higher conversion from SEO to product pages. Can you update that number at all for 3Q?

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Real quick, the 10% conversion hold, we continue to feel pretty good about that. So no real update on that. Specific to Q4, the guidance, as you called out, was 4% to 6% FX-neutral revenue growth with EPS $0.52 to $0.54, up 4% to 8%. Specific to the
componenttext: Sure. Real quick, the 10% conversion hold, we continue to feel pretty good about that. So no real update on that. Specific to Q4, the guidance, as you called out, was 4% to 6% FX-neutral revenue growth with EPS $0.52 to $0.54, up 4% to 8%. Specific to the revenue, this really implies underlying continued stability with a couple of dynamics worth noting. First off, you called out one of them, the StubHub lapping. We'll have 3 months of lapping versus just a month of lapping in Q4, which will decelerate -- have an impact to decelerating our overall total revenue. And we have about 1 point of some non-repeating VAT settlements in Q3 that I called out in my prepared remarks. So those 2 will have an impact on the overall revenue growth that we called out. I would characterize the underlying revenue growth at 4% to 6% as relatively stable quarter-to-quarter. And then we expect the initiatives to continue on the positive trajectory that we've called out but not yet having this massive inflection point or date that everyone's looking for. We continue to see progress. We'll continue to elevate the experience via structured data and user experience. We expect us to continue to see some benefits in mobile and C2C but really continue to focus on our strategic initiatives plus really lean in on our Q4 holiday plans. And then we'll talk more about '17 in January.

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Robert Peck from SunTrust.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Robert Peck from SunTrust.

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Kunal for Robert. Sorry about the noise. A question on MercadoLibre and the rationale for divesting that stake. You already have $2.7 billion of cash in the U.S. You're buying back about $500 million of shares every quarter. Could that indicate th
componenttext: This is Kunal for Robert. Sorry about the noise. A question on MercadoLibre and the rationale for divesting that stake. You already have $2.7 billion of cash in the U.S. You're buying back about $500 million of shares every quarter. Could that indicate that maybe the board or management is thinking in terms of maybe issuing a onetime dividend?

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, as I indicated in my prepared remarks, we've sold the majority of our stake in MercadoLibre. And if the greenshoe is exercised, we'll have sold all of our stake in MercadoLibre. And really, this is driven by the fact that we regularly review and activ
componenttext: No, as I indicated in my prepared remarks, we've sold the majority of our stake in MercadoLibre. And if the greenshoe is exercised, we'll have sold all of our stake in MercadoLibre. And really, this is driven by the fact that we regularly review and actively manage our investments as part of our disciplined capital allocation strategy. The sale's going to enable us to recognize a significant gain. It'll be about $1.2 billion of gross proceeds and about $700 million to $800 million of net gain. If the shoe exercises, that'll be in addition to that. This is a Q4 event, and we're working through the U.S. and international tax implications of this, the timing of the cash payments, which may impact free cash flow, but this does not change our capital allocation strategy nor our relationship with MELI. We have a great relationship with them, and we've actually signed an agreement with them to expand our relationship to help connect our sellers to Latin America buyers.

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Mark May from Citi.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Mark May from Citi.

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think most of mine have been answered by now but just going back to the Q4 outlook, just given all the focus on the Marketplace numbers and given sort of the changes that are going on in the quarter with StubHub to decel. Maybe if you could shed a littl
componenttext: I think most of mine have been answered by now but just going back to the Q4 outlook, just given all the focus on the Marketplace numbers and given sort of the changes that are going on in the quarter with StubHub to decel. Maybe if you could shed a little bit more light on kind of what your guidance assumes in terms of Marketplace GMV and/or revenue growth or maybe the inverse. Give us a sense of exactly -- or more of a sense of how much you expect StubHub revenue to decelerate. And then a question on M&A. I think Devin, you've talked about this in the past, and my impression is that, to the extent that you are looking at acquisitions, they've been relatively small and kind of tuck-in strategic. Has your view changed recently on that?

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Hey, Mark, first on your first question, look, the underlying growth assumptions of 4% to 6% for the total company, about 1 point -- we expect about 1 point of StubHub deceleration and about 1 point of VAT deceleration -- or lapping that we'll have t
componenttext: Yes. Hey, Mark, first on your first question, look, the underlying growth assumptions of 4% to 6% for the total company, about 1 point -- we expect about 1 point of StubHub deceleration and about 1 point of VAT deceleration -- or lapping that we'll have to factor in. We don't give guidance by platform per se, but realistically speaking, the way I would think about it is we're roughly stable quarter-to-quarter in our implied guidance. Devin, I don't know if you want to take the...

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. On the part of your question vis-à-vis M&A, nothing changes. We have a business that generates high free cash flow. We have a strong balance sheet. We have been able to return a meaningful amount of capital to shareholders. As you heard in Scott's r
componenttext: Yes. On the part of your question vis-à-vis M&A, nothing changes. We have a business that generates high free cash flow. We have a strong balance sheet. We have been able to return a meaningful amount of capital to shareholders. As you heard in Scott's remarks, we're going to likely continue to do that. And that still provides us the flexibility to do acquisitions where we see that we can create value, and we won't hesitate to do that. I don't think we've said a lot about big versus small. It's more about being disciplined about what we do. I -- we wouldn't hesitate to do something larger if we thought that we could create sustainable long-term value in doing it. And right now we've built capabilities, particularly in areas like AI and a little bit of geo expansion through small tuck ins, and it's likely to continue. But if we saw the opportunity to do something more meaningful, we wouldn't hesitate to do it, but we'll be disciplined about it. We don't swing wildly at things.

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Mark Mahaney from RBC.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Mark Mahaney from RBC.

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The acceleration in international FX-neutral GMV growth, is there anything you'd call out from any particular countries that may have contributed to that? Or do you view that really as more consistent with what you've seen the last couple of quarters? And
componenttext: The acceleration in international FX-neutral GMV growth, is there anything you'd call out from any particular countries that may have contributed to that? Or do you view that really as more consistent with what you've seen the last couple of quarters? And then secondly, the switch to the longer-cycle marketing campaign, is there a time you want to put out to test whether that shift in marketing works? Is that something you're going to try for a year and then assess at that point? I guess, the underlying question there is really how long will it take in order to figure out whether that shift in marketing strategy is working.

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Mark, on the first half of the question, international was really just rounding up 1 point. I wouldn't characterize it to be any different than the prior quarter. So to answer your question, no, I wouldn't flag anything. Devin, on the marketing [ph]
componenttext: Yes. Mark, on the first half of the question, international was really just rounding up 1 point. I wouldn't characterize it to be any different than the prior quarter. So to answer your question, no, I wouldn't flag anything. Devin, on the marketing [ph] .

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark. Vis-à-vis marketing, we are a very measurement-oriented company as you know. And the reason that, historically, we've been somewhat averse to moving our marketing up the funnel is because it gets harder to measure value. It's easy to measure v
componenttext: Yes, Mark. Vis-à-vis marketing, we are a very measurement-oriented company as you know. And the reason that, historically, we've been somewhat averse to moving our marketing up the funnel is because it gets harder to measure value. It's easy to measure value when you're marketing down the funnel, and it gets harder as you move up. But that doesn't mean there is no value. So we have a way -- we are going to do -- as we increase the amount of up-the-funnel brand marketing, we are going to do our best at measuring value. It certainly needs a longer time frame. I think it is at least a year in which it needs to be in the market to really resonate and start to shift the perception consideration of the eBay brand. And we're going to watch it. It's not -- that's not the kind of thing you watch everyday like you do down-the-funnel marketing, but we're certainly going to watch it carefully. We've got a measurement framework for it. We'll hold it ultimately for the same standard that we hold any investment we make, but it is a little bit a longer cycle than what we're used to. And we'll take -- we will need to leave it on and have the discipline to leave it on over a longer time frame to know if it works.

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Scott Devitt from Stifel.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Scott Devitt from Stifel.

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Devin, and just to beat a dead horse, as you get on the back of the structured data transition, which does allow you to offer better experiences for consumers, you noted earlier that it won't show up in a single quarter but over time. And I'm just wonderi
componenttext: Devin, and just to beat a dead horse, as you get on the back of the structured data transition, which does allow you to offer better experiences for consumers, you noted earlier that it won't show up in a single quarter but over time. And I'm just wondering if you see the outcome is going to be a GMV growth that's going to be sustained around current levels with these new experiences in place. Or do you have conviction that growth will improve? You just don't have a defined time horizon of getting there. And then secondly for Scott, have you put further thought -- has the board discussed any further instituting a quarterly dividend?

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks for the question. We -- look, I mean, obviously, we believe that the sum of the activity that we're doing can drive higher revenue growth -- GMV growth. We do believe that. The time frame will be what it is in some respect, and we'll be as agg
componenttext: Yes. Thanks for the question. We -- look, I mean, obviously, we believe that the sum of the activity that we're doing can drive higher revenue growth -- GMV growth. We do believe that. The time frame will be what it is in some respect, and we'll be as aggressive as we can. And it will be a kind of slower burn in the sense that it isn't a 1-quarter wire on. It'll roll in as we roll these experiences in, which will be a build over quarters. But I don't -- we have certainly not changed our original philosophy that we believe that there can be higher growth in this business given what we're doing.

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Scott, I mean, we're not changing our capital allocation strategy based on the sale of the MELI asset. The reality is, is we have a pretty well clearly defined 2016 buyback that we'll continue to execute, and then I would expect, to some level, that'
componenttext: Yes. Scott, I mean, we're not changing our capital allocation strategy based on the sale of the MELI asset. The reality is, is we have a pretty well clearly defined 2016 buyback that we'll continue to execute, and then I would expect, to some level, that'll continue in the future. But it's not going to -- it's not changing how we're thinking about capital allocation and our strategy around that.

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our final question for today comes from the line of Brian Fitzgerald from Jefferies.
componenttext: And our final question for today comes from the line of Brian Fitzgerald from Jefferies.

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe 2 quick ones. On the Corrigon acquisition, how quickly does that type of tech get integrated? And then any updates on integration efforts with Ticket Utils and SalesPredict? And then finally on StubHub, what percentage of venues are you live in with
componenttext: Maybe 2 quick ones. On the Corrigon acquisition, how quickly does that type of tech get integrated? And then any updates on integration efforts with Ticket Utils and SalesPredict? And then finally on StubHub, what percentage of venues are you live in with the VR tech? And how should we look at rolling it out to further venues?

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent, thanks for the question. So on Corrigon, we have been working with Corrigon previously, and the answer is it's already wired on. If you look at the collective experience that we launched this week, it's actually using Corrigon to do background
componenttext: Excellent, thanks for the question. So on Corrigon, we have been working with Corrigon previously, and the answer is it's already wired on. If you look at the collective experience that we launched this week, it's actually using Corrigon to do background image improvement. It's a great experience. If you haven't seen it, please go look at it. Just type collective into eBay search, and go take a look at that vertical experience. That is using the Corrigon technology to, in essence, take seller images and improve them and remove the backgrounds and make them look just about museum quality. So the answer is we're already using it, and we'll expand the use of that over time. Vis-à-vis the other acquisitions like SalesPredict and Expertmaker, we are already starting to use that in the more back-end part of the structured data initiative to create catalogs and taxonomies, which is happening with pace. So all of these things -- almost all -- I think -- I believe all 3 of them, we have been working with prior to buying them. And they are wired on now and they are -- they'll come online with even more spectrum over time. Vis-à-vis the VR rollout of StubHub, I think I have said that it's now 55 venues, which -- and we'll just keep marching down that path because customers are actually using it. I think we've got one of the best use cases for VR actually driving commerce, and it makes sense. It's an immersive experience. It's a high ASP sale. And we're learning from that about how we might bring VR into more core eBay activities, where immersion matters, where high ASP drives careful consideration of the visual image before purchase. So we like VR and augmented reality, and we think they're going to be meaningful in commerce, and we want to be a leader there.

headline: eBay Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 19, 2016
